pageContent:
© 2023 Bruce Monger
Climate Change

CLIMATE CHANGE ACTION BY PAST CORNELL STUDENTS
In 2011
 Cornell and 
Ithaca College Students 
traveled to Washington 
DC to join others in 
asking President Obama 
to reject the Keystone XL 
Pipeline — President 
Obama heard their voices 
and responded in 2015 by 
cancelling the permit...
In 2014
 Cornell Students 
traveled to NYC to join 
others in asking leaders to 
lead in finding climate 
change solutions — World 
Leaders heard those 
voices and in 2015 
worked to make the Paris 
COP-21 talks a success.
This slideshow focuses a 
lens on 
Cornell 
Students
 at these two 
protests — 
raising 
their voices for 
positive change.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Climate Change

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Outline
1.
Science of Climate Change


2.
Response of the Ocean (beyond what has already been discussed)


• Sea Level Rise 
• Polar Ice Loss 
3.
How Much Longer Can We Keep Burning CO
2
?


4.
Hopeful Signs


5.
Work Ahead

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section I
The Science of Climate Change

© 2023 Bruce Monger
We have burned a lot of 
fossil carbon and discharged 
the CO
2
 waste into our 
atmosphere...
Our Industrial 
Waste Problem...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Concentration of Atmospheric CO
2
 has increased by
 
50%
 
Since the Beginning of the Industrial Era... 
419 ppm
A Super Important 
Point
Atmospheric CO
2
 
concentration is increasing by 
about 2 to 3ppm each year 
https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/carbon-dioxide/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Consequences of Increased Atmospheric CO
2
:  Greenhouse Gas Effect
3.
The short wavelength energy 
is absorbed by the car’s seats/dashboard
 
which warms them and causes them to reradiate the absorbed energy as
 
long wavelength radiation  
(i.e., referred to as 
Infrared Radiation
) 


4.
The window,
 that let 
short wavelength
 radiation through, then absorbs the
 
long wavelength
 radiation emitted by the warm seats and prevents this 
radiation from leaving the car interior.
5.
Because more energy enters the car as short wavelength radiation than leaves the car as long 
wavelength radiation (i.e., there is an energy imbalance), the car begins to heat up
6.
The inside of the car continues to heat (along with the glass) until the glass reaches a temperature 
where the warm glass itself radiates heat energy outward to the sky at the same rate that the sunlight 
energy enters the car.
1.
Recall
 that material is warmed by radiant energy when it absorbs the energy.


2.
Car
 
Interior
 
Analogy:
 
Visible sunlight energy
 (
commonly referred to as short wavelength radiation
) 
passes right through the glass window of a car 
without being absorbed
.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Increased Atmospheric CO
2
 has Created a Persistent Energy 
Imbalance in the Earth System that Accumulates Heat Energy Over 
Time — Like rolling up the window on your car a little bit further
1.
The same amount of sunlight (short wavelength) 
energy is still coming into the earth each day, but 
less infrared (long wavelength) energy is leaving the 
earth through the atmosphere and back out to 
space...


2.
The energy imbalance is about 
2 watts/m
2
 
 
i.e., 
2 Joules of heat energy per second
 is 
accumulating over each square meter of the earth.
 


3.
This heat energy accumulates 
second-by-second, 
hour-by-hour; day-by-day; year-by-year 
— and so 
the earth warms.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Temperature Anomalies Since the Industrial Era
 
1.1
 °C Rise in Global Average Temperature
1.
Limiting global warming to 
 
1.5°C
 above pre-industrial levels is 
the widely accepted upper limit of 
warming expressed by the 
international community.


2.
To  give you some perspective...
 
during the last ice age
 there was 
one kilometer of ice laying on top of 
Ithaca and global average 
temperatures were just 
4 °C
 colder 
Two Important Points... 
Temperatures are Relative to Base
Period 1951-1980
http://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/graphs/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2023/08/03/july-blows-away-temperature-records-testing-key-climate-threshold/
Global Average Temperatures 
Reach 1.5 ºC This Past July (2023)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Natural Rise and Fall of 
Atmospheric CO
2,
 Global 
Temperatures and Sea Level 
Over Geologic Time Scales
http://www.ccdatacenter.org/PageFact.aspx?FactPageID=9&Categories=YES
Atmospheric CO
2
 
 
varied between 
180 to 280 ppm


Global Average Temperature
 
varied by about 
4 ºC
 
 
with some peaks to troughs extremes 
that are close to 
6 ºC


Global Average Sea Level
 
varied by 
100 meters

© 2023 Bruce Monger
For 800,000 years 
orbital variations 
(
Milankovitch Forcing
)
 altered ocean 
circulation that, in turn, allowed CO
2
 to 
move between the deep ocean and the 
atmosphere and this caused glacial and 
interglacial cycles.   


•
The best that 
orbital variations
 could 
do
 
was drive atmospheric CO
2
 up to 
280 ppm
.
 
•
Humans 
have now come along and 
driven CO
2 
to
 419 ppm
Present CO
2 
 
(419 ppm)
Putting Things Into Perspective...
Interglacial CO
2
 (280 ppm)
Glacial CO
2
 (180 ppm)
Humans are now more powerful than the orbital variations at drove our past ice ages!  
We
 can now stop an ice age!!!
See Also: https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2021/03/extreme-climate-change-history/617793/
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41561-022-00920-7.pdf

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Human civilization developed during
 
a period of remarkably stable 
climate that began 10,000 years ago.  


We
 now risk leaving that stability behind with human-caused 
climate change.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_temperature_record
Temperature of Planet Earth
Home sapiens 
400,000 years ago
Hominids 
2 million years ago
Human Civilization 
5,000 years ago

© 2023 Bruce Monger
How confident are we that humans are largely responsible 
for the observe global warming???
The Answers Is:  
Very Confident!!!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Human Forcing
 
is much 
larger than 
Natural Forcing
 
— 
By a Long Ways!
 
Magnitudes of Human and 
Natural Climate Forcing at 
Decade Time Scales
https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-climate-forcing
Forcing is measured in watts per 
meter square energy imbalance 
each component produces.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global Temperature Increase  
versus Cumulative CO
2
 Emissions
https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/figures/summary-for-policymakers/figure-spm-10
Cumulative CO
2
 Emissions Since 1850
Global Temperature Increase 
Note!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
2.
By accounting for 
both
 natural forcing 
and
 forcing 
by greenhouse gas emissions CO
2
 and 
deforestation (
ORNGE LINE
), are we able to 
recreate the observed temperature increases 
(
BLACK LINE
) since the industrial era. 


2.
The fact that dozens of different numerical 
models created by different groups of scientists 
around the world get basically the same answer 
for their numerical experiments provides strong 
evidence that humans are largely responsible for 
the increase in global temperature observed 
since the industrial 
   
Numerical Experiments:  Strong Attribution of Human Cause
1.
If we account 
only
 for natural forcing (solar & volcanos etc...) in climate models (
BLUE LINE
), we are not able to 
recreate the observed increase in global temperature (
BLACK LINE
).
http://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2015-whats-warming-the-world/
See:
https://www.epa.gov/sites/default/files/2021-05/graph2_0.png

© 2023 Bruce Monger
According to the IPCC* 6th Assessment Report (AR6)
It is 
Unequivocal
 that human influence has warmed the 
atmosphere, ocean and land.  
* IPCC: The United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/downloads/report/IPCC_AR6_WGI_SPM.pdf

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section II
Contribution of Methane Emissions to Climate Change

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Carbon Dioxide (CO
2
)  
Climate system responds slowly to changes, but current 
emissions will influence climate for 100s of years 
with residual 
effects lasting thousands of years
.
Carbon Dioxide versus Methane 
Methane (CH
4
) 
Much faster response by climate system. 
Methane
 
stays in 
atmosphere for only a decade or so.
 


220 times more CO
2
 in atmosphere, but 
CH
4
 is 105 times 
more powerful as a greenhouse gas (by weight)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Carbon Dioxide
Methane
The radiative forcing by methane 
adds an additional 50% (1-watt m
-2
) 
to the forcing by carbon dioxide alone 
(1.7-watts m
-2
).
The Importance of 
Methane to Overall 
Greenhouse Gas Forcing

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1. Clear recognition that warming 
beyond 1.5 deg C is dangerous


2. Methane reductions are critical; 
we cannot reach the COP21 target 
with CO
2
 reductions alone.
COP21 Paris Accord:

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Rather than stabilizing atmospheric 
methane concentrations, there has 
been an significant acceleration in the 
contraction of atmospheric methane 
starting in 2007
The observed acceleration of methane 
in the atmosphere has led to active 
research into the emission source 
responsible for the observed increase.
Recent Increases of 
Methane in the Atmosphere

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
The total flux of methane to the atmosphere is well constrained.


2.
Ancient and new methane can be distinguished based on level of C
14
 of the methane.  
Old methane is depleted of C
14
  from decay over a long time period.


•
Ancient Methane
 —
 formed in rock formations over geological time frame (e.g., 
Natural Gas)


•
New Methane
 —
 Methane formed by decomposition of organic matter by bacteria 
in absence of oxygen


3.
There are natural and anthropogenic sources of methane to the atmosphere 


•
Natural
 source can be 
ancient or new
 (geological seeps or marshlands)


•
Anthropogenic
 source can be 
ancient or new
 (gas extraction or animal agriculture)
Methane Accounting...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://phys.org/news/2016-12-surge-methane-emissions-threatens-efforts.html
About 60%
, of total methane 
inputs to the atmosphere 
come from human activities 
associated with the combined 
effects of fossil fuels and 
agriculture.


Teasing out the relative 
human contributions
 from 
fossil fuels and agricultural 
has been difficult and is still an 
area of active research... 
Anthropogenic 
Methane Inputs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
An Important Point About Methane and Tipping Points ... 
1.
Methane Has a Remarkably Short Half-Life in the Atmosphere


•
If we reduced emissions now, methane would quickly be reduced in the atmosphere 
and we would get a quick reduction on global warming 


2.
As Increases in CO
2
 Push Global Temperature Close to Natural Tipping Points...


•
methane reduction might be the simplest way to rapidly reduce warming and 
avoid crossing a tipping point of no return.
Climate Tipping Points:  
Points in the climate system when positive feedbacks begin 
and the climate spins out of human control.


•
Methane Release from Thawing Permafrost


•
Melting of Methane Clathrates (methane ice) Found Along Continental Shelf Sea 
Floors.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section III
Response of the Ocean to Global Warming
Sea Level Rise

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Average Sea Level is 
Currently About
 
1/4 Meter
 
Above Pre-Industrial Levels.
Sea Level Rise
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Contributions to Sea Level Rise
http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/OceanCooling/page5.php
http://www.grida.no/publications/rr/in-dead-water/page/1246.aspx
Roughly half of the current sea-level increase is due to 
 
thermal expansion
 and the other half is due to 
melting land ice
.
Thermal 
Expansion
Land Ice

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Melting Ice Sheets

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Melting Ice Sheets

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level
With Business as Usual emissions, sea level is expected to reach 
1-Meter 
on a global average by the end of the century
, but some models predict 
this rise could be reached much sooner.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Spatial Trend Pattern in Sea Level 
Rise 1993 to 2010 from Merged 
Satellite Altimetry Products
Cazenave and Remy (2011)
Sea level and climate: measurements and causes of changes
WIREs Clim Change 2011, 2: 647-662. doi: 10.1002/wcc.139
Sea Level Rise is Not 
Evenly Distributed

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2022/02/15/sea-level-rise-2050-climate/
Sea Level Rise Along 
US Coastlines 
An additional foot by 2050
•
“We’re unfortunately headed for
 
  a 
flood regime shift.
” 
•
“There will be water in the
 
  streets”
William Sweet, 
Oceanographer at the NOAA 
National Ocean Service and the nation’s top scientist 
on sea level rise.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sea level is committed to rise for 
Hundreds to Thousands of Years
 and 
Will Remain Elevated for Thousands of Years
.
Over the next 2,000 years, global mean sea level will  rise: 
•
2 to 3 m
 if warming is limited to 
1.5°C
,


•
2 to 6 m
 if limited to 
2°C
 


•
19 to 22 m
 if warming reached 
5.0°C
 


And it will continue to rise over subsequent millennia. 
https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/downloads/report/IPCC_AR6_WGI_SPM.pdf
According to IPCC AR6

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Vulnerabilities of Coastal Communities 
to Sea Level Rise

© 2023 Bruce Monger
US coastal areas at risk to a sea 
level rise (1 meter) by the end of 
this century (red regions)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Populations and Assets at 
risk to a 1-meter sea level rise 
at the end of this century...
http://carnegieendowment.org/2013/05/16/protecting-coastal-cities-from-rising-seas
•
Tens of 
millions
 of people


•
Ten of 
trillions
 of dollars in assets

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Retreat  
Accommodate 
Protect

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section IV
Response of the Ocean to Global Warming
Arctic Sea Ice Loss

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Global warming is not 
evenly distributed over 
the earth  


Polar regions are 
especially sensitive due 
to loss of albedo effect
Spatial Distribution 
of Global Warming
https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/149321/2021-continued-earths-warming-trend
In some parts of the Arctic, temperature rise is 
four times
 higher than 
the global average.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
In 2007 the fabled Northwest Passage opened 
for the first time in human history. It has opened 
again several times since then...
Sea Ice Extent (10
6
 km
2
)
Average Monthly Sea Ice Extent
 
July 1979-2023
Year
http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/2023/08/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://interactive.carbonbrief.org/when-will-the-arctic-see-its-first-ice-free-summer/
If temperatures rise by 2C
 – the upper limit set by the Paris 
Agreement – the Arctic has a one-in-five chance of seeing its first 
ice-free summer in 
2035
.


If global temperatures are limited to 1.5C,
 the Arctic is “very 
unlikely” to see its first ice-free summer before
 
2065
.
When Will the Arctic Be Largely Ice-Free in the Summer?

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Arctic Ecosystems Issues: The Good and the Bad for Fishermen & Fisherwomen...
The Good 
1.
Extended ice-free season means in 
increase fishing vessel access
. 


2.
Some favorite 
southern species are becoming more common


•
For example, Pacific salmon have moved into Arctic waters and may become an important food source 
for subsistence fishermen along Alaska’s north coast.


The Bad 
3.
New species entering an existing ecosystem may 
threaten existing populations
. 


•
For example, Atlantic cod have been displacing polar cod in the waters surrounding the Svalbard 
Archipelago.  


4.
Rising temperatures and an influx of fresh water from melting ice can cause 
rippling effects through the 
marine food chain.
 


•
For example, scientists project that ocean warming will cause
 shifts in the spawning and feeding 
grounds
 of several economically-important fish populations with potential downside consequences. 
Arctic Matters: Global Connection To Changes in the Arctic , National Research Council of the National Academies. 2015,
  http://nas-sites.org/arctic

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Political Sparing for 
Rights to the Arctic...
Two big issues are at stake in 
the arctic
1.
Vast oil reserves under the sea 
floor of the arctic


2.
Shipping lanes between US East 
Coast or Western Europe and all of 
Asia

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://interactive.carbonbrief.org/when-will-the-arctic-see-its-first-ice-free-summer/
Interactive: When will the Arctic see its first ice-free summer?
Optional Reading

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/22/climate/arctic-sea-ice-minimum.html
Optional Reading

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2015/03/antarctica-rapidly-losing-its-edge
1.
Some stations in East Antarctica show some 
cooling, but in general Antarctica is
 
warming up. 


2.
The West Antarctic Peninsula is one of the fastest 
warming areas on Earth, with only some areas in 
the Arctic experiencing faster rising temperatures.


3.
The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is losing
 
mass, 
likely due to warmer ocean water near the 
coast.  
4.
West Antarctica has lost 18% of is ice sheet 
volume over the last two decades.
Changes in the Antarctica
Antarctic surface temperature trends for 1957-2006.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Ecosystem Changes in West 
Antarctica
1.
Krill is a Keystone Species on the Southern Ocean: Food 
for a broad array of predators


2.
Most
 
Antarctic krill
 
are found in an area from the Weddell 
Sea to the waters around the Antarctic Peninsula


3.
Over the past 40 years
, populations of adult Antarctic 
krill have declined by 
70 to 80 percent
 in these areas. 


4.
Model projections
*
 predict that by 2100 suitable 
habitat for young krill will decline by
 
up to 80%.
http://www.climatecentral.org/news/climate-change-could-put-tiny-krill-at-risk-20641
*  A. Piñones and A. Fedorov 
 
    Geophysical Research Letters,  10.1002/2016GL069656

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Other Climate Change Impacts You Should Be 
Worried About...
Extreme Weather (lecture later this semester)


Global Food Security


National Security

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Coral Bleaching


Ocean Acidification


Ocean Deoxygenation


Disruption to Conveyor Belt Circulation
And Don’t Forget These Impacts We Have Already 
Covered....

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section V
1.
How Much Longer Can We Keep Emitting CO
2


2.
Prospects for Changing Things

© 2023 Bruce Monger
How Much Longer Can We Keep Emitting CO
2
?
The Short Answer: 
Not Much Longer!!!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Paris Climate Talks December 2015...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/jun/02/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-paris-climate-summit-and-un-talks
https://phys.org/news/2018-04-degrees-longer-global-guardrail.html#jCp
1. We
 aspire to limit warming to 1.5 
º
C 
•
to reach this goal, we must 
rapidly
 reduce global emissions to 
half by 2030 
and 
net zero by 2050


2.
To  maintain stable human societies we must not exceed 2 
º
C  
•
to reach this goal, we must 
steadily
 reduce global carbon 
emissions to
 net zero by 2050
The Paris COP-21 Climate Action Consensus Statement


Agreed Upon by Essentially Every Leader of Every Nation on Planet Earth

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Nations responsible for 90% of global emissions came up with their respective 
pledges at COP21 – known in the UN jargon as 
Intended Nationally Determined 
Contributions or INDCs.  
•
Analysis of the INDCs has suggested that these pledges would only be enough to 
hold the world to about 
2.7ºC or 3ºC of warming
.  


•
One of the key components of any Paris agreement
 was to 
institute a system 
of review of the emissions targets every five years, with a view to ratcheting 
them downwards.
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/jun/02/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-paris-climate-summit-and-un-talks
Note: The Paris Climate Talks:  A Hopeful Start, But Only a Start...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Glasgow COP 26 (2021)
Was suppose to get nations to make new 
Intended National Determined 
Commitments
 (INDC)
 to reduce emission to prevent warming beyond 1.5ºC. 


We
 are still a long ways away from the emission reductions needed to 
stay below 1.5ºC warming.
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/11/01/climate/paris-pledges-tracker-cop-26.html

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Glasgow COP 26
United States and 100 Other Nations Announce 
Agreement to 
Reduce Methane Emissions 30% 
by 2030
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/02/climate/biden-methane-climate.html

© 2023 Bruce Monger
IPCC AR6:  Mitigation of Climate Change
Since you get to decide the leaders, the future is up to YOU!
https://www.vox.com/23009894/un-ipcc-climate-mitigation-report-ar6-summary
Readily available technology across the economy could slash pollution 
in half by 2030,
 but it depends more on the level of political courage 
by government leaders to implement these changes.
1.
Solar and wind are the least expensive and most e
ff
ective action we can take. 
2.
Agriculture, industry, and parts of the transportation sector remain toughest to decarbonize


3.
There are other pollutants besides carbon dioxide we have to worry about (
e.g., methane
)


4.
Politics, Not Technology
, Will Determine the Course of Climate Change
https://www.carbonbrief.org/solar-is-now-cheapest-electricity-in-history-confirms-iea/

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Prospects for Changing Things...
Every So Often a Generation is Called Upon to do Something Extraordinary

© 2023 Bruce Monger
RECALL:
 Human civilization developed during
 
a period of 
remarkably stable climate that began 10,000 years ago.  


We
 now risk leaving that stability behind with human-caused 
climate change.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_temperature_record
Temperature of Planet Earth
Home sapiens 
400,000 years ago
Hominids 
2 million years ago
Human Civilization 
5,000 years ago

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Much of the CO
2
 we put into the atmosphere lingers 
in the atmosphere for up to 10,000 years. 
Consequently, there has always been a fixed budget of 
CO
2
 that could be emitted before crossing critical global 
warming thresholds.


Past generations have brought humanity up against 
these critical thresholds
Cumulative CO
2
 Emissions
2.0 
0
C Budget
Year 2050
1.5 
0
C Budget
Year 2030
A Line In The Sand
2023
This generation now faces a proverbial 
line in the sand to either cross or not cross these 
warming thresholds.
https://royalsociety.org/topics-policy/projects/climate-change-evidence-causes/question-20/
https://theconversation.com/if-we-stopped-emitting-greenhouse-gases-right-now-would-we-stop-climate-change-78882
https://www.npr.org/2021/04/14/981333730/carbon-emissions-could-plummet-the-atmosphere-will-lag-behind

© 2023 Bruce Monger
We/You Have a Choice to Make
This generation now faces a choice
 
to either rise up and be truly heroic or to 
shrink back and be small and say it is 
too complex or too costly and do 
nothing.


The future of human civilization literally 
depends on this choice.


Either way, this generation’s choice 
will be judged by future generations 
for the next 10,000 years!!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Every so often a generation is called upon to 
do something extraordinary... 
 


•
In 1940 a generation was asked to rise up and fight a world war.


•
This current generation is now being called upon to rise to an 
even greater challenge — 
to decarbonize the global energy 
system of the planet in two decades to save all of humanity.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Prospects for Changing Things...
Hopeful Signs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Living “sustainably” does NOT 
have to mean sacrificing 
comfort.  Quite the contrary, it 
can mean a much richer life!
Thriving in a 
Sustainable Future...
First of All — Change Can Be a Good Thing!!!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What We
 Have Today is Really 
Primitive!
๏
We currently dig stuff out of the ground and we 
light it on fire for our energy!


•  We
 are just one step above burning logs in a cave! 
๏
And then literally millions of people choke to 
death each year on the smoke!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
I Strongly Prefer This World Instead!

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Prospects for Changing Things...
Hopeful Signs

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/new-report-maps-out-the-u-s-road-to-net-zero-emissions/?fbclid=IwAR3C0Yrxo_4Obb2gS9mBBY-54CYCd3xKCDTl-TGQFF06_hyJjJJG7rmwxKs
National Academy of Science 
2021 Report: 
Outlines Pathway to Net Zero Emissions
Policies to get the US to net zero 
emission would produce a cleaner 
energy system, 
high-quality jobs
 and 
improve international 
competitiveness 
The report warns, however, that this 
will require heavy political lifting by 
Congress and future administrations.
https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/0716bb9a-6138-4918-8023-cb24caa47794/NetZeroby2050-ARoadmapfortheGlobalEnergySector.pdf
https://e360.yale.edu/features/the-dream-of-co2-air-capture-edges-toward-reality?fbclid=IwAR1ukwpUM3CtqGK0zBX9lkUQA_gdRRZfMLQFOY8zNtFoirANFYEb_Yl8YaY

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Paris COP 21 Nationally 
Determined Commitments (NDC)
President Biden announced a US goal 
of cutting emissions 
50% by 2030
.   
This would begin to put the world on 
a path for achieving a 1.5 ºC limit!!

•
IPCC AR6
 notes that to keep the planet’s average 
temperature from rising more than 1.5 degrees Celsius 
above its pre-industrial level 
a billion tons (or more) 
of carbon dioxide will need to be removed each 
year
 


•
An alliance of prominent Silicon Valley companies—
including Google—
has committed to purchase 
nearly a billion dollars in carbon removal over the 
next eight years.  
•
By committing upfront to buying a product early, 
they hope to help bring it to market faster.

Large-Scale Wind and Solar: The Growing Local Backlash
This e
ff
ort involves building a gigantic fleet 
of solar panels and towering turbines that 
are wired to homes and businesses.


The Problem:
 It will require us to bulldoze 
or build over some places that people 
treasure.  Resistance is often rooted in 
personal anxiety about social and 
economic change. But in some cases the 
resistance involves organized groups with 
funding from fossil fuel interests.

Deep Sea Mining: How The Process Works
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/deep-sea-mining-could-begin-soon-regulated-or-not/
One machine, over a 30-year contract, could strip 
10,000 square kilometers of seabed.


As the big machines crawl along, they will suspend 
large amounts of fine sediment. Scientists have little 
evidence for what the e
ff
ects might be, but it is 
plausible the plume could smother sedentary 
creatures such as sea anemones and sponges.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Deep Sea Mining: The International Seabed Authority (ISA)
The ISA has approved over two dozen ocean floor mining 
exploration
 contracts since 1994.  
Contractors have up to 15 years to explore their claim areas. 


The ISA met in July 2023 and made progress on draft regulations to govern seabed 
extraction
. 
But it did 
not
 adopt the regulations that would have given the go-ahead for 
extraction
 to begin.  
Instead, the ISA announced a roadmap for continued work that targets adopting them in 
2025
.


It's not just environmentalists
 who are concerned; 
governments and, even corporations that 
want the minerals in the nodules, have taken a stand against mining in international waters
, 
at least until the potential impacts of deep-sea mining can be fully assessed. 
The growing chorus 
of voices includes France, Germany and Chile; BMW and Google; and more than 700 
experts.
